Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 05:56PM Msklapkin wrote: I had an ooph because I was BRCA2+.  My onc would not let a regular gyn do the surgery.  He insisted it be done by a gynecological oncologist. Many of us went to Breast surgeons for our breast, so I suggest you see a gynecological oncologist for your ovaries.  any surgery should be done and recommended by those who do it most often. speak to a specialist to get a clearer picture. good luck susan
Posts.Title: oopherectomy even if menopausal? water wallan

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 09:13AM Msklapkin wrote: Hi I was diagnosed and then discovered I was BRCA2+ I had bilateral mastecomy with expanders. that was 3 years ago- I am now NED and very  happy with my silicone girls NEVER a day of regret! Hubby and I are so happy I am here and I sleep so much better Good luck with your decision susan
Posts.Title: Should I have a full mastectomy? BooBee kjcsis

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2008 04:15PM Msklapkin wrote: mshubba, It is natural to be worried.  Try to enjoy the holiday as best you can.  Know that you are so being strong and doing the right thing going for these tests.  The waiting and the test are the hardest part of the journey. We are here to help you thru this- you will get thru it! Based upon your family history- have you had genetic testing?  Knowledge is power and really helps with all decisions. Good luck
Posts.Title: New and worried mshubba mshubba

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 03:41PM Msklapkin wrote: Hi Heather, A doctor who treat ovarian cancer is usually a Gynocological Oncologist=this dr deals with cervical, ovararin, uterine cancers, etc.  This is who I went to to have my ovaries removed.  As a gynecological oncology surgeeon, she does not do breast surgery when I had my mastectomies, I went to a Breast Surgeon who deals with Breast Cancer.  Of course, she does not remove ovaries! they are different specialties just as they are differnt cancers. Same thing with an oncologist- some specialize in Liver cancer or Breast cancer. Oncology is a very big field- make sure you go to a specialist in your surgery and they do it often I also agree with the post that said most Breast Surgeons deal with Breast Cancer and should be able to answer all questions you may have. A surgeon who does breast "augmentation" is a Plastic Surgeon,not a Breast surgeon usually I hope this helps you.  Good Luck- If you tell us where you are, we can help you find docs in the area
Posts.Title: Who Should I Be Seeing? Heather_Hu SandyinSoCal

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2008 07:04AM Msklapkin wrote: Ailenroc, I am on Lexapro and it helps.  I am 3 years out and my docs suggest I stay on it! We have gone thru a horrible trauma both physically and mentally-what you are feeling is totally normal. I have met some incredible women on this board and surround myself with them when I get blue.  No one else truly can understand how we feel. I too have missed the "old me" and my life BC(before cancer) but my terrific friends tell me we never would have met-their friendship is so special, I can't imagine that either. We are here to help you. Susan
Posts.Title: I'm not depressed ... just sad ailenroc ailenroc

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 06:11AM Msklapkin wrote: I was 50 when I was dx with BC, so my situation is different.  I had BC in my left breast and Thank G-d it was my surgeon who recommended the test.  My maternal aunt had died of BC and I am ashkenazi Jew.  Once I tested + I had a bilateral mastectomy with expanders and oopherectomy when my exchange surgery was done.  It was the easiest decision I EVER made.  Never a second thought and so happy I did-it helps me sleep much better.  I could not imagine going thru life waiting for the second shoe to drop. My genetic counsellor did tell me if my 29 yr old niece had the gene mutation(she does not) they would not recommend such drastic surgery at her age.  When you do have your breasts checked, in addition to mammography, if you are high risk you should have ultrasound and MRI.  Mine WAS NOT found on mammogram, but was clear on ultrasound. My belief is knowledge is power when it comes to fighting cancer and early detection is the best cure. Good luck with whatever you choose Susan
Posts.Title: BRCA test I_Run_For_Hope cdsouza

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 05:57PM Msklapkin wrote: I was same as Liz, Nodes removed only on my cancer side- no nodes removed on Prophylactic side. i did have an MRI on the good side first- just to make sure no questionable areas before surgery Good luck susan
Posts.Title: Another SNB Needed? What Do You Think? Aug242007 Aug242007

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2007 02:58PM Msklapkin wrote: ilenee, First-take a deep breath or 2.  We have all been where you are-hearing the stats and then finding out we are in that group.  You are not in a minority here.  I am sorry you had to come here but you will find strenght and company on this site. Believe it or not, you will start to feel better after you meet with the docs so try not to be afraid. You are in the worst part of the journey right now- waiting, test results, unknown, doctor visits, questions, etc.  Just know once you have a knowledge and a game plan you will feel better-then you will have control. You obviously are a fighter since you fought with your doc to have a mammo-good for you-keep that spirit up.  I am sorry you had to lose your mom to this disease.  Please understand BC is like snowflakes- each one is different.  And treatments are getting better every day. Treat yourself well- you are special- enjoy the holidays-concentrate on the positive as hard as it may be.  And always remember-take a deep breath! I got my dx 2 1/2 years ago and am enjoying life!  You will too. all the best of luck to you susan
Posts.Title: just diagnosed and SCARED!!! ilenee ilenee

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2007 01:22PM Msklapkin wrote: The oncologist said that the BRCA genes are more a concern in younger women  Corepat- I do not understand this comment at all.  does that mean if I am 52 and have the BRCA mutation I do not have to worry- Of course not!  Anyone having the BRCA mutation needs to worry about OC and BC no matter what age!!  At 52 my onc strongly suggested I have an oopherectomy. I think what this means is if women are tested young and are positive, they can have more surveillance or make decisions about their breasts and ovaries earlier-for example- start Mammograms at 30 instead of 40. BC and OC have no age limitations- I know women in their 20's and women in their 80's  and everyone in between.  Each is a valuable life and should be monitored and treated to live a long happy life.  Just because we are over 50 we should not ignore the tools we have to save us. I think your questions are best answered by a doctor and I strongly suggest you see a genetic councellor.  It may be BRCA or a different mutation due to the cluster.  Only by more testing and more info can doctors do their research. Please know each case is individual-just because your Grandmother got it at 53 does not mean if you pass 53 you are safe.  Please test yourself and since you are at high risk, you should have additional testing- MRI, IU ultrasound, etc.  I wish you luck with whatever they find on your mammogram. Please understand I am a 2+ year survivor with the BRCA2 mutation.  I wish I had know and could have found my tumor earlier- before it spread to my sentinal node. Good luck susan
Posts.Title: Age and BRCA testing corepat veggievet

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 01:06AM Msklapkin wrote: I had a ductal excision due to a discharge.  It is a really simple surgery-done as an out patient. I had 2 opinions- one said take only problem duct and other said take all- I chose to have all ducts taken.  It just caused a small scar on my areole.  The good news is- It had NOTHING TO DO WITH BREAST CANCER-I hope yours is the same good luck to you susan
Posts.Title: Pending Duct Excision.....PLEASE HELP Rene48 Grannyx2

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 02:42PM Msklapkin wrote: HI Linda, I am BRCA2+ and a 2 year Breast cancer survivor. I have not had to deal with this. I read an article recently that said Ovarian Cancer usually starts on the fallopian tubes, not the ovaries. My onclolgist was insistant that my oopherectomy be done by a gynocological oncologist and NOT my gynecologist. she removed my ovaries, fallopian tubes and dida peritoneal wash. I hope this helps you Best of luck Susan
Posts.Title: Peritoneal Cancer dcissurvivor dcissurvivor

Posts.Content: Msklapkin wrote: I was dx with triple neg breast cancer in Aug '05. BRCA 2+ had double mastectomy with expanders, dose dense chemo and oopherectomy.  Now more than 2 years out from chemo and onc was thrilled. Went to new endocrinologist (hypothyroid + osteoperosis)because we moved.  He thought he saw a nodule on my thyroid and is sending me for a complete ultra sound.  Old endo said if anything suspicious do a biopsy. There is that "B" word again and I am freaking out. Anyone have mets to thyroid or experience with thyroid cancer?  the more I read, they seem like may be connected. Looking for info. thanks to you all Susan Dx 8/8/2005, IDC, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 1/8 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Thyroid Nodule? Msklapkin Honeybear

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 11:57AM Msklapkin wrote: Hi Sally, yes, I was hyper thyroid 12 years prior to my BC dx.  I had 3 iodine treatments at that time and feel there may be a correlation as well as my genetic predisposition. All I can do is make sure I get my thyroid checked and treated any way necessary- I just hate to have to deal with health issues again.  I guess all the researchers are still trying to connect the dots! UGH! just when I thought life was getting back to normal! Thanks for the info Susan
Posts.Title: Thyroid Nodule? Msklapkin Honeybear

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 08:43PM Msklapkin wrote: I am sorry it took so long to finish this thread. After a FNA and then a core biopsy of the the thyroid IT IS BENIGN!!! It has been a couple of weeks since I got the news- but it is sinking in slowly- no cancer! Yeah!
Posts.Title: Thyroid Nodule? Msklapkin Honeybear

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2008 12:06AM Msklapkin wrote: Renee I had a spontaneous discharge- it only happened every few weeks- The doctors were able to force it out.  They explained it did not happen all the time because sometimes it was just a little bit of blood there- not enough to come out. Mine was caused by a papilloma that was benign. I had a complete ductal excision.  It was an easy day surgery and the nipple looked a little crooked but not bad at all.  I had a small scar on the areole It really is not bad and definitely worth having it taken care of. It was this papilloma in my right breast that caused the doc to check both and found my lump in the LEFT breast.  That little papilloma saved my life- I always think it was Gods flag! good luck Live laugh and love
Posts.Title: Pending Duct Excision.....PLEASE HELP Rene48 Grannyx2

Posts.Content: May 15, 2008 10:50AM Msklapkin wrote: Hi Wish You can also try website-facingourrisk.org It is a webiste specifically to deal with BRCA- you may find women in your area who can help. My oncologist worked with a genetic cousellor and she was quite helpful, so an oncologist may be another source. Good luck- I wish more BS would discuss genetic testing BEFORE our surgeries. I did mine before my axillary node dissection and chose double mastectomy with reconstruction all at the same time Susan

If you go to the website-facingourrisk.org you will find many women who were tested at all ages. I am not sure why your sister's onc brought up age-since BC or OC can show up at any age. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2008 09:48AM Msklapkin wrote: Hi Becky, I will answer your question as best I can.  I had a core needle biopsy.  It WAS NOT painful at all. I was given an injection to numb the area and then they took the samples.  I even drove to Atlantic City afterward and spent the next 2 days in meetings for work. I also had a core needle biopsy of my thyroid and the experience was the same. Speak to your doctor and BREATH!! Wishing you the best of luck for B9 results Susan

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 11:18AM Msklapkin wrote: Hello, We all understand- Take a deep breath and try to relax-ask the doctor if you feel you need soemthing to help you relax- this is normal. when you go to the doctor, try not to go alone or bring a tape recorder- it may be hard to remember everything that is said.  Take notes and ask questions as you go along- don't worry about stopping the doctor to ask for an explanation.  It is important that you be as clear about your options and treatments as possible.  as you think of questions before your appointment, write them down and come here for answers. Now- take one day at a time- try not to think about what if's etc- there is nothing you can do about that- try to live in the moment-that is the only certainty. Face each day with strength and pat youself on the back each night for all you accomplished that day. I am sorry we had to meet this way, but know so many of us have been where you are right now and have survived and prospered as people- you will get love and strength here and know- YOU WILL GET THRU THIS! You are in our prayers Good Luck Susan
